Question: Suppose you are an Elite academic, why is it that older adults seem to resist new technologies compared to younger adults?
Answer: Older adults often resist new technologies compared to younger adults due to a combination of factors. These include a higher degree of technological inertia, as they may have less prior exposure to digital innovations, making new technologies seem more foreign. There can be a learning curve barrier, as they might find it more challenging to learn and adapt to new interfaces due to cognitive and physical changes associated with aging. Additionally, older adults may have less necessity or motivation to adopt new tech if their current tools meet their needs. Cultural and generational attitudes also play a role, as younger generations have grown up with technology as an integral part of their lives. Trust in technology and perceived usability are other important factors contributing to this difference.

Question: Suppose you are an Elite academic, why do some social sciences face more skepticism compared to natural sciences and engineering?
